stance_1: A meal without meat feels incomplete
justification: The feeling that a meal without meat is incomplete is explicitly supported by the enjoyment of eating meat.

stance_1: A meal without meat feels incomplete
stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: Trying to eat more vegetables than meat implicitly conflicts with the feeling that meals without meat are incomplete.

stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: Liking to eat meat conflicts implicitly with the effort to eat more vegetables than meat.

stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: The belief that vegetables are healthier explicitly supports the effort to eat more vegetables than meat.

stance_1: I think vegetables are more delicious
stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: Believing vegetables are more delicious explicitly supports eating more vegetables than meat.

stance_1: Meat can get tiring if eaten too much
stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: The idea that meat can get tiring if eaten too much explicitly supports eating more vegetables than meat.

stance_1: My family eats more meat than I do
stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: The interviewee contrasts their own higher vegetable and lower meat consumption with their family's higher meat intake.

stance_1: My friends eat more meat than I do
stance_2: I try to eat more vegetables than meat
justification: The interviewee contrasts their own higher vegetable and lower meat consumption with their friends' higher meat intake.

stance_1: My family eats more meat than I do
stance_2: My family enjoys the taste of meat
justification: It is explicitly stated that the family's higher meat consumption is due to their enjoyment of the taste.

stance_1: My friends eat more meat than I do
stance_2: My friends enjoy the taste of meat
justification: It is explicitly stated that the friends' higher meat consumption is due to their enjoyment of the taste.
